dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Let fame, that all hunt after in their lives, Live registered upon our brazen tombs, And then grace us in the disgrace of death; When, spite of cormorant devouring time, Th' endeavour of this present breath may buy That honour which shall bate his scythe's keen edge, And make us heirs of all eternity. Therefore, brave conquerors, for so you are That war against your own affections And the huge army of the world's desires, Our late edict shall strongly stand in force. Navarre shall be the wonder of the world; Our court shall be a little academe, Still and contemplative in living art. You three, Berowne, Dumaine and Longaville, Have sworn for three years' term to live with me, My fellow-scholars, and to keep those statutes That are recorded in this schedule here. Your oaths are passed, and now subscribe your names, That his own hand may strike his honour down That violates the smallest branch herein. If you are armed to do as sworn to do, Subscribe to your deep oaths, and keep it too.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: I am resolved. 'Tis but a three years' fast. The mind shall banquet, though the body pine. Fat paunches have lean pates, and dainty bits Make rich the ribs, but bankrupt quite the wits.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: My loving lord, Dumaine is mortified. The grosser manner of these world's delights He throws upon the gross world's baser slaves. To love, to wealth, to pomp, I pine and die, With all these living in philosophy.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I can but say their protestation over. So much, dear liege, I have already sworn, That is, to live and study here three years. But there are other strict observances: As not to see a woman in that term, Which I hope well is not enrolled there; And one day in a week to touch no food, And but one meal on every day beside, The which I hope is not enrolled there; And then to sleep but three hours in the night, And not be seen to wink of all the day, When I was wont to think no harm all night, And make a dark night too of half the day, Which I hope well is not enrolled there. O, these are barren tasks, too hard to keep, Not to see ladies, study, fast, not sleep.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Your oath is passed to pass away from these.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Let me say no, my liege, an if you please. I only swore to study with your Grace And stay here in your court for three years' space.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: You swore to that, Berowne, and to the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: By yea and nay, sir, then I swore in jest. What is the end of study, let me know?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Why, that to know which else we should not know.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Things hid and barred, you mean, from common sense?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Ay, that is study's god-like recompense.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Come on, then, I will swear to study so, To know the thing I am forbid to know: As thus, to study where I well may dine, When I to feast expressly am forbid; Or study where to meet some mistress fine, When mistresses from common sense are hid; Or, having sworn too hard-a-keeping oath, Study to break it, and not break my troth. If study's gain be thus, and this be so, Study knows that which yet it doth not know. Swear me to this, and I will ne'er say no.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: These be the stops that hinder study quite, And train our intellects to vain delight.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Why, all delights are vain, but that most vain Which, with pain purchased, doth inherit pain: As painfully to pore upon a book To seek the light of truth, while truth the while Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his look. Light seeking light doth light of light beguile; So, ere you find where light in darkness lies, Your light grows dark by losing of your eyes. Study me how to please the eye indeed By fixing it upon a fairer eye, Who dazzling so, that eye shall be his heed, And give him light that it was blinded by. Study is like the heaven's glorious sun, That will not be deep-searched with saucy looks; Small have continual plodders ever won, Save base authority from others' books. These earthly godfathers of heaven's lights, That give a name to every fixed star, Have no more profit of their shining nights Than those that walk and wot not what they are. Too much to know is to know naught but fame, And every godfather can give a name.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: How well he's read, to reason against reading.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Proceeded well, to stop all good proceeding.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: He weeds the corn, and still lets grow the weeding.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: The spring is near when green geese are a-breeding.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: How follows that?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Fit in his place and time.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: In reason nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Something then in rhyme.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Berowne is like an envious sneaping frost That bites the first-born infants of the spring.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Well, say I am. Why should proud summer boast Before the birds have any cause to sing? Why should I joy in any abortive birth? At Christmas I no more desire a rose Than wish a snow in May's new-fangled shows, But like of each thing that in season grows. So you, to study now it is too late, Climb o'er the house to unlock the little gate.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Well, sit you out. Go home, Berowne. Adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: No, my good lord, I have sworn to stay with you, And though I have for barbarism spoke more Than for that angel knowledge you can say, Yet confident I'll keep what I have sworn And bide the penance of each three years' day. Give me the paper, let me read the same, And to the strictest decrees I'll write my name.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: How well this yielding rescues thee from shame.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: _Item, That no woman shall come within a mile of my court._ Hath this been proclaimed?

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Four days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Let's see the penalty.  _On pain of losing her tongue._ Who devised this penalty?

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Marry, that did I.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Sweet lord, and why?

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: To fright them hence with that dread penalty.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: A dangerous law against gentility.  _Item, If any man be seen to talk with a woman within the term of three years, he shall endure such public shame as the rest of the court can possibly devise._ This article, my liege, yourself must break, For well you know here comes in embassy The French King's daughter, with yourself to speak- A mild of grace and complete majesty- About surrender up of Aquitaine To her decrepit, sick, and bedrid father. Therefore this article is made in vain, Or vainly comes th' admired Princess hither.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What say you, lords? Why, this was quite forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: So study evermore is overshot. While it doth study to have what it would, It doth forget to do the thing it should; And when it hath the thing it hunteth most, 'Tis won as towns with fire: so won, so lost.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: We must of force dispense with this decree. She must lie here on mere necessity.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Necessity will make us all forsworn Three thousand times within this three years' space; For every man with his affects is born, Not by might mastered, but by special grace. If I break faith, this word shall speak for me: I am forsworn on mere necessity. So to the laws at large I write my name, And he that breaks them in the least degree Stands in attainder of eternal shame. Suggestions are to other as to me; But I believe, although I seem so loath, I am the last that will last keep his oath. But is there no quick recreation granted?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Ay, that there is. Our court, you know, is haunted With a refined traveller of Spain, A man in all the world's new fashion planted, That hath a mint of phrases in his brain; One who the music of his own vain tongue Doth ravish like enchanting harmony, A man of complements, whom right and wrong Have chose as umpire of their mutiny. This child of fancy, that Armado hight, For interim to our studies shall relate In high-born words the worth of many a knight From tawny Spain lost in the world's debate. How you delight, my lords, I know not, I, But I protest I love to hear him lie, And I will use him for my minstrelsy.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Armado is a most illustrious wight, A man of fire-new words, fashion's own knight.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Costard the swain and he shall be our sport, And so to study three years is but short.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: Which is the Duke's own person?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: This, fellow. What wouldst?

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: I myself reprehend his own person, for I am his Grace's farborough. But I would see his own person in flesh and blood.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: This is he.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: Signior Arm… Arm… commends you. There's villainy abroad. This letter will tell you more.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Sir, the contempts thereof are as touching me.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: A letter from the magnificent Armado.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: How long soever the matter, I hope in God for high words.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: A high hope for a low heaven. God grant us patience!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: To hear, or forbear laughing?

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: To hear meekly, sir, and to laugh moderately, or to forbear both.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Well, sir, be it as the style shall give us cause to climb in the merriness.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: The matter is to me, sir, as concerning Jaquenetta. The manner of it is, I was taken with the manner.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: In what manner?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: In manner and form following, sir, all those three. I was seen with her in the manor-house, sitting with her upon the form, and taken following her into the park, which, put together, is "in manner and form following". Now, sir, for the manner. It is the manner of a man to speak to a woman. For the form-in some form.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: For the "following", sir?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: As it shall follow in my correction, and God defend the right!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Will you hear this letter with attention?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: As we would hear an oracle.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Such is the simplicity of man to hearken after the flesh.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _Great deputy, the welkin's vicegerent and sole dominator of Navarre, my soul's earth's god and body's fostering patron-_

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Not a word of Costard yet.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _So it is-_

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: It may be so; but if he say it is so, he is, in telling true, but so.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Peace!

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Be to me, and every man that dares not fight.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: No words!

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Of other men's secrets, I beseech you.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _So it is, besieged with sable-coloured melancholy, I did commend the black-oppressing humour to the most wholesome physic of thy health-giving air; and, as I am a gentleman, betook myself to walk. The time when? About the sixth hour, when beasts most graze, birds best peck, and men sit down to that nourishment which is called supper. So much for the time when. Now for the ground which? Which, I mean, I walked upon. It is ycleped thy park. Then for the place, where? Where, I mean, I did encounter that obscene and most preposterous event that draweth from my snow-white pen the ebon-coloured ink, which here thou viewest, beholdest, surveyest, or seest. But to the place where? It standeth north-north-east and by east from the west corner of thy curious-knotted garden. There did I see that low-spirited swain, that base minnow of thy mirth-_

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Me?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _That unlettered small-knowing soul-_

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Me?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _That shallow vassal-_

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Still me?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _Which, as I remember, hight Costard-_

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: O me!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _Sorted and consorted, contrary to thy established proclaimed edict and continent canon, which with, O, with-but with this I passion to say wherewith-_

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: With a wench.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _With a child of our grandmother Eve, a female; or, for thy more sweet understanding, a woman. Him, I, as my ever-esteemed duty pricks me on, have sent to thee, to receive the meed of punishment, by thy sweet Grace's officer, Antony Dull, a man of good repute, carriage, bearing, and estimation._

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: Me, an't shall please you; I am Antony Dull.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: _For Jaquenetta, so is the weaker vessel called which I apprehended with the aforesaid swain, I keep her as a vessel of thy law's fury, and shall, at the least of thy sweet notice, bring her to trial. Thine, in all compliments of devoted and heartburning heat of duty, Don Adriano de Armado._

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: This is not so well as I looked for, but the best that ever I heard.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Ay, the best for the worst. But, sirrah, what say you to this?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Sir, I confess the wench.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Did you hear the proclamation?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I do confess much of the hearing it, but little of the marking of it.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: It was proclaimed a year's imprisonment to be taken with a wench.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I was taken with none, sir. I was taken with a damsel.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Well, it was proclaimed "damsel".

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: This was no damsel neither, sir; she was a virgin.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: It is so varied too, for it was proclaimed "virgin".

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: If it were, I deny her virginity. I was taken with a maid.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: This maid will not serve your turn, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: This maid will serve my turn, sir.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Sir, I will pronounce your sentence: you shall fast a week with bran and water.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I had rather pray a month with mutton and porridge.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: And Don Armado shall be your keeper. My Lord Berowne, see him delivered o'er; And go we, lords, to put in practice that Which each to other hath so strongly sworn.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I'll lay my head to any good man's hat These oaths and laws will prove an idle scorn. Sirrah, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I suffer for the truth, sir; for true it is I was taken with Jaquenetta, and Jaquenetta is a true girl. And therefore welcome the sour cup of prosperity! Affliction may one day smile again, and till then, sit thee down, sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit grows melancholy?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: A great sign, sir, that he will look sad.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Why, sadness is one and the selfsame thing, dear imp.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: No, no, O Lord, sir, no.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: How canst thou part sadness and melancholy, my tender juvenal?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: By a familiar demonstration of the working, my tough signior.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Why tough signior? Why tough signior?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Why tender juvenal? Why tender juvenal?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I spoke it, tender juvenal, as a congruent epitheton appertaining to thy young days, which we may nominate tender.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: And I, tough signior, as an appertinent title to your old time, which we may name tough.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Pretty and apt.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: How mean you, sir? I pretty and my saying apt, or I apt, and my saying pretty?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Thou pretty, because little.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Little pretty, because little. Wherefore apt?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: And therefore apt, because quick.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Speak you this in my praise, master?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: In thy condign praise.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: I will praise an eel with the same praise.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: What, that an eel is ingenious?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: That an eel is quick.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I do say thou art quick in answers. Thou heat'st my blood.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: I am answered, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I love not to be crossed.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: He speaks the mere contrary; crosses love not him.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I have promised to study three years with the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: You may do it in an hour, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: How many is one thrice told?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I am ill at reckoning. It fitteth the spirit of a tapster.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I confess both. They are both the varnish of a complete man.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Then I am sure you know how much the gross sum of deuce-ace amounts to.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: It doth amount to one more than two.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Which the base vulgar do call three.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: True.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Why, sir, is this such a piece of study? Now here's three studied ere ye'll thrice wink. And how easy it is to put "years" to the word "three", and study three years in two words, the dancing horse will tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: A most fine figure!

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: To prove you a cipher.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I will hereupon confess I am in love; and as it is base for a soldier to love, so am I in love with a base wench. If drawing my sword against the humour of affection would deliver me from the reprobate thought of it, I would take desire prisoner, and ransom him to any French courtier for a new-devised curtsy. I think scorn to sigh; methinks I should outswear Cupid. Comfort me, boy. What great men have been in love?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Hercules, master.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Most sweet Hercules! More authority, dear boy, name more; and, sweet my child, let them be men of good repute and carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Samson, master. He was a man of good carriage, great carriage, for he carried the town gates on his back like a porter, and he was in love.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: O well-knit Samson, strong-jointed Samson! I do excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst me in carrying gates. I am in love too. Who was Samson's love, my dear Moth?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: A woman, master.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Of what complexion?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of the four.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Tell me precisely of what complexion.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Of the sea-water green, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Is that one of the four complexions?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: As I have read, sir; and the best of them too.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Green indeed is the colour of lovers. But to have a love of that colour, methinks Samson had small reason for it. He surely affected her for her wit.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: It was so, sir, for she had a green wit.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: My love is most immaculate white and red.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Most maculate thoughts, master, are masked under such colours.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Define, define, well-educated infant.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: My father's wit and my mother's tongue assist me!

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sweet invocation of a child, most pretty, and pathetical!

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: If she be made of white and red, Her faults will ne'er be known; For blushing cheeks by faults are bred, And fears by pale white shown. Then if she fear, or be to blame, By this you shall not know, For still her cheeks possess the same Which native she doth owe. A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason of white and red.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Is there not a ballad, boy, of the King and the Beggar?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: The world was very guilty of such a ballad some three ages since, but I think now 'tis not to be found; or if it were, it would neither serve for the writing nor the tune.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I will have that subject newly writ o'er, that I may example my digression by some mighty precedent. Boy, I do love that country girl that I took in the park with the rational hind Costard. She deserves well.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: To be whipped: and yet a better love than my master.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sing, boy. My spirit grows heavy in love.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: And that's great marvel, loving a light wench.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I say, sing.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Forbear till this company be past.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: Sir, the Duke's pleasure is that you keep Costard safe; and you must suffer him to take no delight, nor no penance, but he must fast three days a week. For this damsel, I must keep her at the park. She is allowed for the dey-woman. Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I do betray myself with blushing.-Maid.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: Man.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I will visit thee at the lodge.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: That's hereby.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I know where it is situate.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: Lord, how wise you are!

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I will tell thee wonders.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: With that face?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I love thee.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: So I heard you say.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: And so, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: Fair weather after you!

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: Come, Jaquenetta, away.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offences ere thou be pardoned.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Well, sir, I hope when I do it I shall do it on a full stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I am more bound to you than your fellows, for they are but lightly rewarded.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Take away this villain. Shut him up.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Come, you transgressing slave, away!

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Let me not be pent up, sir. I will fast being loose.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: No, sir, that were fast and loose. Thou shalt to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Well, if ever I do see the merry days of desolation that I have seen, some shall see.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: What shall some see?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Nay, nothing, Master Moth, but what they look upon. It is not for prisoners to be too silent in their words, and therefore I will say nothing. I thank God I have as little patience as another man, and therefore I can be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I do affect the very ground, which is base, where her shoe, which is baser, guided by her foot, which is basest, doth tread. I shall be forsworn, which is a great argument of falsehood, if I love. And how can that be true love which is falsely attempted? Love is a familiar; Love is a devil. There is no evil angel but Love. Yet was Samson so tempted, and he had an excellent strength; yet was Solomon so seduced, and he had a very good wit. Cupid's butt-shaft is too hard for Hercules' club, and therefore too much odds for a Spaniard's rapier. The first and second cause will not serve my turn; the _passado_ he respects not, the _duello_ he regards not. His disgrace is to be called boy, but his glory is to subdue men. Adieu, valour; rust, rapier; be still, drum, for your manager is in love. Yea, he loveth. Assist me, some extemporal god of rhyme, for I am sure I shall turn sonnet. Devise, wit; write, pen; for I am for whole volumes in folio.

scenes.location: The King of Navarre's park. A pavilion and tents at a distance

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Now, madam, summon up your dearest spirits. Consider who the King your father sends, To whom he sends, and what's his embassy. Yourself, held precious in the world's esteem, To parley with the sole inheritor Of all perfections that a man may owe, Matchless Navarre; the plea of no less weight Than Aquitaine, a dowry for a queen. Be now as prodigal of all dear grace As Nature was in making graces dear When she did starve the general world beside And prodigally gave them all to you.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Good Lord Boyet, my beauty, though but mean, Needs not the painted flourish of your praise. Beauty is bought by judgement of the eye, Not uttered by base sale of chapmen's tongues. I am less proud to hear you tell my worth Than you much willing to be counted wise In spending your wit in the praise of mine. But now to task the tasker: good Boyet, You are not ignorant, all-telling fame Doth noise abroad Navarre hath made a vow, Till painful study shall outwear three years, No woman may approach his silent court. Therefore to's seemeth it a needful course, Before we enter his forbidden gates, To know his pleasure; and in that behalf, Bold of your worthiness, we single you As our best-moving fair solicitor. Tell him the daughter of the King of France, On serious business craving quick dispatch, Importunes personal conference with his Grace. Haste, signify so much, while we attend, Like humble-visaged suitors, his high will.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Proud of employment, willingly I go.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: All pride is willing pride, and yours is so. Who are the votaries, my loving lords, That are vow-fellows with this virtuous Duke?

dialogues.speaker: Lord
dialogues.line: Lord Longaville is one.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Know you the man?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: I know him, madam. At a marriage feast Between Lord Perigort and the beauteous heir Of Jaques Falconbridge, solemnized In Normandy, saw I this Longaville. A man of sovereign parts, he is esteemed, Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms. Nothing becomes him ill that he would well. The only soil of his fair virtue's gloss, If virtue's gloss will stain with any soil, Is a sharp wit matched with too blunt a will, Whose edge hath power to cut, whose will still wills It should none spare that come within his power.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Some merry mocking lord, belike. Is't so?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: They say so most that most his humours know.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Such short-lived wits do wither as they grow. Who are the rest?

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: The young Dumaine, a well-accomplished youth, Of all that virtue love for virtue loved; Most power to do most harm, least knowing ill, For he hath wit to make an ill shape good, And shape to win grace though he had no wit. I saw him at the Duke Alençon's once; And much too little of that good I saw Is my report to his great worthiness.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Another of these students at that time Was there with him, if I have heard a truth. Berowne they call him, but a merrier man, I never spent an hour's talk withal. His eye begets occasion for his wit, For every object that the one doth catch The other turns to a mirth-moving jest, Which his fair tongue, conceit's expositor, Delivers in such apt and gracious words That aged ears play truant at his tales, And younger hearings are quite ravished, So sweet and voluble is his discourse.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: God bless my ladies! Are they all in love, That every one her own hath garnished With such bedecking ornaments of praise?

dialogues.speaker: Lord
dialogues.line: Here comes Boyet.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Now, what admittance, lord?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Navarre had notice of your fair approach, And he and his competitors in oath Were all addressed to meet you, gentle lady, Before I came. Marry, thus much I have learned: He rather means to lodge you in the field, Like one that comes here to besiege his court, Than seek a dispensation for his oath, To let you enter his unpeopled house. Here comes Navarre.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Fair Princess, welcome to the court of Navarre.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: "Fair" I give you back again, and "welcome" I have not yet. The roof of this court is too high to be yours, and welcome to the wide fields too base to be mine.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: You shall be welcome, madam, to my court.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: I will be welcome then. Conduct me thither.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Hear me, dear lady. I have sworn an oath.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Our Lady help my lord! He'll be forsworn.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Why, will shall break it; will, and nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Your ladyship is ignorant what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Were my lord so, his ignorance were wise, Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance. I hear your Grace hath sworn out housekeeping. 'Tis deadly sin to keep that oath, my lord, And sin to break it. But pardon me, I am too sudden bold. To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me. Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming, And suddenly resolve me in my suit.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Madam, I will, if suddenly I may.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: You will the sooner that I were away, For you'll prove perjured if you make me stay.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I know you did.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: How needless was it then To ask the question!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: You must not be so quick.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: 'Tis long of you that spur me with such questions.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Your wit's too hot, it speeds too fast, 'twill tire.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Not till it leave the rider in the mire.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: What time o' day?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: The hour that fools should ask.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Now fair befall your mask.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Fair fall the face it covers.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: And send you many lovers!

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Amen, so you be none.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Nay, then will I be gone.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Madam, your father here doth intimate The payment of a hundred thousand crowns, Being but the one half of an entire sum Disbursed by my father in his wars. But say that he or we, as neither have, Received that sum, yet there remains unpaid A hundred thousand more, in surety of the which One part of Aquitaine is bound to us, Although not valued to the money's worth. If then the King your father will restore But that one half which is unsatisfied, We will give up our right in Aquitaine, And hold fair friendship with his majesty. But that, it seems, he little purposeth; For here he doth demand to have repaid A hundred thousand crowns, and not demands, On payment of a hundred thousand crowns, To have his title live in Aquitaine, Which we much rather had depart withal, And have the money by our father lent, Than Aquitaine, so gelded as it is. Dear Princess, were not his requests so far From reason's yielding, your fair self should make A yielding 'gainst some reason in my breast, And go well satisfied to France again.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: You do the King my father too much wrong, And wrong the reputation of your name, In so unseeming to confess receipt Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I do protest I never heard of it; And, if you prove it, I'll repay it back Or yield up Aquitaine.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: We arrest your word. Boyet, you can produce acquittances For such a sum from special officers Of Charles his father.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Satisfy me so.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: So please your Grace, the packet is not come Where that and other specialties are bound. Tomorrow you shall have a sight of them.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: It shall suffice me; at which interview All liberal reason I will yield unto. Meantime receive such welcome at my hand As honour, without breach of honour, may Make tender of to thy true worthiness. You may not come, fair Princess, in my gates, But here without you shall be so received As you shall deem yourself lodged in my heart, Though so denied fair harbour in my house. Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell. Tomorrow shall we visit you again.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Sweet health and fair desires consort your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Thy own wish wish I thee in every place.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Lady, I will commend you to mine own heart.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Pray you, do my commendations; I would be glad to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I would you heard it groan.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Is the fool sick?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Sick at the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Alack, let it blood.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Would that do it good?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: My physic says "ay".

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Will you prick't with your eye?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: _Non point_, with my knife.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Now, God save thy life.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: And yours from long living.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I cannot stay thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Sir, I pray you, a word. What lady is that same?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: The heir of Alençon, Katharine her name.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: A gallant lady. Monsieur, fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: I beseech you a word. What is she in the white?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: A woman sometimes, an you saw her in the light.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Perchance light in the light. I desire her name.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: She hath but one for herself; to desire that were a shame.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Pray you, sir, whose daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Her mother's, I have heard.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: God's blessing on your beard!

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Good sir, be not offended. She is an heir of Falconbridge.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Nay, my choler is ended. She is a most sweet lady.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Not unlike, sir; that may be.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: What's her name in the cap?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Rosaline, by good hap.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Is she wedded or no?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: To her will, sir, or so.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: You are welcome, sir. Adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Farewell to me, sir, and welcome to you.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: That last is Berowne, the merry madcap lord. Not a word with him but a jest.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: And every jest but a word.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: It was well done of you to take him at his word.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Two hot sheeps, marry!

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: And wherefore not ships? No sheep, sweet lamb, unless we feed on your lips.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: You sheep and I pasture. Shall that finish the jest?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: So you grant pasture for me.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Not so, gentle beast. My lips are no common, though several they be.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Belonging to whom?

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: To my fortunes and me.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Good wits will be jangling; but, gentles, agree. This civil war of wits were much better used On Navarre and his bookmen, for here 'tis abused.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: If my observation, which very seldom lies, By the heart's still rhetoric disclosed with eyes, Deceive me not now, Navarre is infected.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: With what?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: With that which we lovers entitle "affected".

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Your reason.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Why, all his behaviours did make their retire To the court of his eye, peeping thorough desire. His heart, like an agate, with your print impressed, Proud with his form, in his eye pride expressed. His tongue, all impatient to speak and not see, Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be; All senses to that sense did make their repair, To feel only looking on fairest of fair. Methought all his senses were locked in his eye, As jewels in crystal for some prince to buy; Who, tend'ring their own worth from where they were glassed, Did point you to buy them, along as you passed. His face's own margent did quote such amazes That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes. I'll give you Aquitaine, and all that is his, An you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Come, to our pavilion. Boyet is disposed.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: But to speak that in words which his eye hath disclosed. I only have made a mouth of his eye By adding a tongue which I know will not lie.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Thou art an old love-monger, and speakest skilfully.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: He is Cupid's grandfather, and learns news of him.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Then was Venus like her mother; for her father is but grim.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Do you hear, my mad wenches?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: What, then, do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Ay, our way to be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: You are too hard for me.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Warble, child, make passionate my sense of hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Concolinel.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sweet air! Go, tenderness of years, take this key, give enlargement to the swain, bring him festinately hither. I must employ him in a letter to my love.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Master, will you win your love with a French brawl?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: How meanest thou? Brawling in French?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: No, my complete master; but to jig off a tune at the tongue's end, canary to it with your feet, humour it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometime through the throat, as if you swallowed love with singing love, sometime through the nose, as if you snuffed up love by smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like o'er the shop of your eyes, with your arms crossed on your thin-belly doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your hands in your pocket like a man after the old painting; and keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away. These are compliments, these are humours; these betray nice wenches that would be betrayed without these; and make them men of note-do you note me?-that most are affected to these.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: How hast thou purchased this experience?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: By my penny of observation.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: But O-but O-

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: "The hobby-horse is forgot."

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Call'st thou my love "hobby-horse"?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: No, master. The hobby-horse is but a colt, and your love perhaps a hackney. But have you forgot your love?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Almost I had.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Negligent student! Learn her by heart.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: By heart and in heart, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: And out of heart, master. All those three I will prove.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: What wilt thou prove?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: A man, if I live; and this, "by, in, and without," upon the instant: "by" heart you love her, because your heart cannot come by her; "in" heart you love her, because your heart is in love with her; and "out" of heart you love her, being out of heart that you cannot enjoy her.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I am all these three.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: And three times as much more, and yet nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Fetch hither the swain. He must carry me a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: A message well sympathized: a horse to be ambassador for an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Ha, ha, what sayest thou?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, you must send the ass upon the horse, for he is very slow-gaited. But I go.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: The way is but short. Away!

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: As swift as lead, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: The meaning, pretty ingenious? Is not lead a metal heavy, dull, and slow?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: _Minime_, honest master; or rather, master, no.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I say lead is slow.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: You are too swift, sir, to say so. Is that lead slow which is fired from a gun?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sweet smoke of rhetoric! He reputes me a cannon; and the bullet, that's he. I shoot thee at the swain.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Thump then, and I flee.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: A most acute juvenal, voluble and free of grace! By thy favour, sweet welkin, I must sigh in thy face. Most rude melancholy, valour gives thee place. My herald is returned.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: A wonder, master! Here's a costard broken in a shin.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Some enigma, some riddle. Come, thy _l'envoi_ begin.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: No egma, no riddle, no _l'envoi_, no salve in the mail, sir. O, sir, plantain, a plain plantain! No _l'envoi_, no _l'envoi_, no salve, sir, but a plantain.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: By virtue, thou enforcest laughter; thy silly thought, my spleen; the heaving of my lungs provokes me to ridiculous smiling. O, pardon me, my stars! Doth the inconsiderate take _salve_ for _l'envoi_, and the word _l'envoi_ for a _salve?_

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Do the wise think them other? Is not _l'envoi_ a _salve?_

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: No, page; it is an epilogue or discourse to make plain Some obscure precedence that hath tofore been sain. I will example it: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee Were still at odds, being but three. There's the moral. Now the _l'envoi_.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: I will add the _l'envoi_. Say the moral again.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee Were still at odds, being but three.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Until the goose came out of door, And stayed the odds by adding four. Now will I begin your moral, and do you follow with my _l'envoi_. The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee Were still at odds, being but three.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Until the goose came out of door, Staying the odds by adding four.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: A good _l'envoi_, ending in the goose. Would you desire more?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: The boy hath sold him a bargain, a goose, that's flat. Sir, your pennyworth is good, an your goose be fat. To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose. Let me see: a fat _l'envoi_-ay, that's a fat goose.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Come hither, come hither. How did this argument begin?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: By saying that a costard was broken in a shin. Then called you for the _l'envoi_.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: True, and I for a plantain. Thus came your argument in. Then the boy's fat _l'envoi_, the goose that you bought; and he ended the market.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: But tell me, how was there a costard broken in a shin?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: I will tell you sensibly.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Thou hast no feeling of it, Moth. I will speak that _l'envoi_. I, Costard, running out, that was safely within, Fell over the threshold and broke my shin.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: We will talk no more of this matter.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Till there be more matter in the shin.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sirrah Costard, I will enfranchise thee.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: O, marry me to one Frances! I smell some _l'envoi_, some goose, in this.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: By my sweet soul, I mean setting thee at liberty, enfreedoming thy person. Thou wert immured, restrained, captivated, bound.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: True, true; and now you will be my purgation, and let me loose.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I give thee thy liberty, set thee from durance, and, in lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but this:  bear this significant to the country maid Jaquenetta.  There is remuneration for the best ward of mine honour is rewarding my dependents. Moth, follow.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Like the sequel, I. Signior Costard, adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: My sweet ounce of man's flesh, my incony Jew! Now will I look to his remuneration. "Remuneration"! O, that's the Latin word for three farthings. Three farthings-_remuneration_. "What's the price of this inkle?" "One penny." "No, I'll give you a remuneration." Why, it carries it! _Remuneration_. Why, it is a fairer name than French crown. I will never buy and sell out of this word.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: My good knave Costard, exceedingly well met.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Pray you, sir, how much carnation ribbon may a man buy for a remuneration?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: What is a remuneration?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Why, then, three-farthing worth of silk.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I thank your worship. God be wi' you.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Stay, slave. I must employ thee. As thou wilt win my favour, good my knave, Do one thing for me that I shall entreat.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: When would you have it done, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: This afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Well, I will do it, sir. Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Thou knowest not what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I shall know, sir, when I have done it.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Why, villain, thou must know first.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I will come to your worship tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: It must be done this afternoon. Hark, slave, it is but this: The Princess comes to hunt here in the park, And in her train there is a gentle lady; When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name, And Rosaline they call her. Ask for her And to her white hand see thou do commend This sealed-up counsel. There's thy guerdon. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Gardon, O sweet gardon! Better than remuneration, a 'levenpence farthing better. Most sweet gardon! I will do it, sir, in print. Gardon! Remuneration!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: And I, forsooth, in love! I, that have been love's whip, A very beadle to a humorous sigh, A critic, nay, a night-watch constable, A domineering pedant o'er the boy, Than whom no mortal so magnificent! This wimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy, This Signior Junior, giant-dwarf, Dan Cupid, Regent of love-rhymes, lord of folded arms, Th' anointed sovereign of sighs and groans, Liege of all loiterers and malcontents, Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces, Sole imperator, and great general Of trotting paritors-O my little heart! And I to be a corporal of his field And wear his colours like a tumbler's hoop! What? I love, I sue, I seek a wife? A woman, that is like a German clock, Still a-repairing, ever out of frame, And never going aright, being a watch, But being watched that it may still go right! Nay, to be perjured, which is worst of all; And, among three, to love the worst of all, A whitely wanton with a velvet brow, With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes; Ay, and, by heaven, one that will do the deed Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard. And I to sigh for her, to watch for her, To pray for her! Go to, it is a plague That Cupid will impose for my neglect Of his almighty dreadful little might. Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue, and groan. Some men must love my lady, and some Joan.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Was that the King that spurred his horse so hard Against the steep uprising of the hill?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: I know not, but I think it was not he.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Whoe'er he was, he showed a mounting mind. Well, lords, today we shall have our dispatch; On Saturday we will return to France. Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush That we must stand and play the murderer in?

dialogues.speaker: Forester
dialogues.line: Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice, A stand where you may make "the fairest shoot".

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: I thank my beauty, I am fair that shoot, And thereupon thou speak'st the fairest shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Forester
dialogues.line: Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: What, what? First praise me, and again say no? O short-lived pride! Not fair? Alack for woe!

dialogues.speaker: Forester
dialogues.line: Yes, madam, fair.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Nay, never paint me now. Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow. Here, good my glass, take this for telling true: Fair payment for foul words is more than due.

dialogues.speaker: Forester
dialogues.line: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: See, see, my beauty will be saved by merit. O heresy in fair, fit for these days! A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise. But come, the bow. Now mercy goes to kill, And shooting well is then accounted ill. Thus will I save my credit in the shoot: Not wounding, pity would not let me do't; If wounding, then it was to show my skill, That more for praise than purpose meant to kill. And out of question so it is sometimes, Glory grows guilty of detested crimes, When, for fame's sake, for praise, an outward part, We bend to that the working of the heart; As I for praise alone now seek to spill The poor deer's blood, that my heart means no ill.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Do not curst wives hold that self-sovereignty Only for praise' sake, when they strive to be Lords o'er their lords?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Only for praise; and praise we may afford To any lady that subdues a lord.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Here comes a member of the commonwealth.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: God dig-you-den all! Pray you, which is the head lady?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the rest that have no heads.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Which is the greatest lady, the highest?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: The thickest and the tallest.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: The thickest and the tallest. It is so, truth is truth. An your waist, mistress, were as slender as my wit, One o' these maids' girdles for your waist should be fit. Are not you the chief woman? You are the thickest here.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: What's your will, sir? What's your will?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I have a letter from Monsieur Berowne to one Lady Rosaline.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: O, thy letter, thy letter! He's a good friend of mine. Stand aside, good bearer. Boyet, you can carve. Break up this capon.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: I am bound to serve. This letter is mistook; it importeth none here. It is writ to Jaquenetta.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: We will read it, I swear. Break the neck of the wax, and everyone give ear.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: _By heaven, that thou art fair is most infallible; true that thou art beauteous; truth itself that thou art lovely. More fairer than fair, beautiful than beauteous, truer than truth itself, have commiseration on thy heroical vassal. The magnanimous and most illustrate King Cophetua set eye upon the pernicious and indubitate beggar Zenelophon, and he it was that might rightly say,_ "Veni, vidi, vici," _which to annothanize in the vulgar-O base and obscure vulgar!_-videlicet, _He came, see, and overcame. He came, one; see, two; overcame, three. Who came? The King. Why did he come? To see. Why did he see? To overcome. To whom came he? To the beggar. What saw he? The beggar. Who overcame he? The beggar. The conclusion is victory. On whose side? The King's. The captive is enriched. On whose side? The beggar's. The catastrophe is a nuptial. On whose side? The King's? No, on both in one, or one in both. I am the King, for so stands the comparison; thou the beggar, for so witnesseth thy lowliness. Shall I command thy love? I may. Shall I enforce thy love? I could. Shall I entreat thy love? I will. What shalt thou exchange for rags? Robes. For tittles? Titles. For thyself? Me. Thus expecting thy reply, I profane my lips on thy foot, my eyes on thy picture, and my heart on thy every part. Thine in the dearest design of industry, Don Adriano de Armado. Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar 'Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey. Submissive fall his princely feet before, And he from forage will incline to play. But if thou strive, poor soul, what are thou then? Food for his rage, repasture for his den._

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: What plume of feathers is he that indited this letter? What vane? What weathercock? Did you ever hear better?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: I am much deceived but I remember the style.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Else your memory is bad, going o'er it erewhile.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: This Armado is a Spaniard that keeps here in court, A phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport To the Prince and his book-mates.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Thou, fellow, a word. Who gave thee this letter?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I told you: my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: To whom shouldst thou give it?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: From my lord to my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: From which lord to which lady?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: From my Lord Berowne, a good master of mine, To a lady of France that he called Rosaline.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away. Here, sweet, put up this: 'twill be thine another day.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Who is the shooter? Who is the shooter?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Shall I teach you to know?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Ay, my continent of beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Why, she that bears the bow. Finely put off!

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: My lady goes to kill horns, but if thou marry, Hang me by the neck if horns that year miscarry. Finely put on!

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Well, then, I am the shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: And who is your deer?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near. Finely put on indeed!

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes at the brow.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: But she herself is hit lower. Have I hit her now?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Shall I come upon thee with an old saying, that was a man when King Pepin of France was a little boy, as touching the hit it?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: So I may answer thee with one as old, that was a woman when Queen Guinevere of Britain was a little wench, as touching the hit it.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it, Thou canst not hit it, my good man.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: An I cannot, cannot, cannot, An I cannot, another can.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: By my troth, most pleasant. How both did fit it!

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: A mark marvellous well shot, for they both did hit it.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: A mark! O, mark but that mark! A mark, says my lady! Let the mark have a prick in't, to mete at, if it may be.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Wide o' the bow hand! I' faith, your hand is out.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Indeed, a' must shoot nearer, or he'll ne'er hit the clout.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: An if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the pin.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Come, come, you talk greasily, your lips grow foul.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: She's too hard for you at pricks, sir. Challenge her to bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: I fear too much rubbing. Good night, my good owl.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: By my soul, a swain, a most simple clown! Lord, Lord, how the ladies and I have put him down! O' my troth, most sweet jests, most incony vulgar wit, When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely, as it were, so fit. Armado, o' the one side, O, a most dainty man! To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan! To see him kiss his hand and how most sweetly he will swear! And his page o' t'other side, that handful of wit! Ah, heavens, it is a most pathetical nit. Sola, sola!

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Very reverend sport, truly, and done in the testimony of a good conscience.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: The deer was, as you know, _sanguis_, in blood, ripe as the pomewater, who now hangeth like a jewel in the ear of _caelo_, the sky, the welkin, the heaven, and anon falleth like a crab on the face of _terra_, the soil, the land, the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Truly, Master Holofernes, the epithets are sweetly varied, like a scholar at the least. But, sir, I assure ye it was a buck of the first head.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Sir Nathaniel, _haud credo_.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: 'Twas not a "auld grey doe", 'twas a pricket.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Most barbarous intimation! Yet a kind of insinuation, as it were, _in via_, in way, of explication; _facere_, as it were, replication, or rather, _ostentare_, to show, as it were, his inclination, after his undressed, unpolished, uneducated, unpruned, untrained, or rather, unlettered, or ratherest, unconfirmed fashion, to insert again my _haud credo_ for a deer.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: I said the deer was not a "auld grey doe", 'twas a pricket.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Twice-sod simplicity, _bis coctus!_ O, thou monster Ignorance, how deformed dost thou look!

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Sir, he hath never fed of the dainties that are bred of a book. He hath not eat paper, as it were; he hath not drunk ink. His intellect is not replenished; he is only an animal, only sensible in the duller parts. And such barren plants are set before us that we thankful should be- Which we of taste and feeling are-for those parts that do fructify in us more than he. For as it would ill become me to be vain, indiscreet, or a fool, So, were there a patch set on learning, to see him in a school. But, _omne bene_, say I, being of an old father's mind; Many can brook the weather that love not the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: You two are bookmen. Can you tell me by your wit What was a month old at Cain's birth, that's not five weeks old as yet?

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Dictynna, goodman Dull. Dictynna, goodman Dull.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: What is Dictynna?

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: A title to Phoebe, to Luna, to the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: The moon was a month old when Adam was no more, And raught not to five weeks when he came to five-score. Th' allusion holds in the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: 'Tis true, indeed. The collusion holds in the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: God comfort thy capacity! I say, th' allusion holds in the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: And I say the pollution holds in the exchange, for the moon is never but a month old; and I say beside that 'twas a pricket that the Princess killed.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Sir Nathaniel, will you hear an extemporal epitaph on the death of the deer? And, to humour the ignorant, call I the deer the Princess killed a pricket.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: _Perge_, good Master Holofernes, _perge_, so it shall please you to abrogate scurrility.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: I will something affect the letter; for it argues facility. The preyful Princess pierced and pricked a pretty pleasing pricket; Some say a sore; but not a sore till now made sore with shooting. The dogs did yell, put "l" to sore, then sorel jumps from thicket; Or pricket sore, or else sorel, the people fall a-hooting. If sore be sore, then "L" to "sore" makes fifty sores o' sorel. Of one sore I an hundred make, by adding but one more "L".

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: A rare talent!

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: If a talent be a claw, look how he claws him with a talent.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: This is a gift that I have, simple, simple; a foolish extravagant spirit, full of forms, figures, shapes, objects, ideas, apprehensions, motions, revolutions. These are begot in the ventricle of memory, nourished in the womb of _pia mater_, and delivered upon the mellowing of occasion. But the gift is good in those in whom it is acute, and I am thankful for it.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Sir, I praise the Lord for you, and so may my parishioners, for their sons are well tutored by you, and their daughters profit very greatly under you. You are a good member of the commonwealth.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Mehercle!_ If their sons be ingenious, they shall want no instruction; if their daughters be capable, I will put it to them. But, _vir sapit qui pauca loquitur_. A soul feminine saluteth us.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: God give you good morrow, Master Person.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Master Person, _quasi_ pierce one. And if one should be pierced, which is the one?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Marry, Master schoolmaster, he that is likest to a hogshead.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Of piercing a hogshead! A good lustre or conceit in a turf of earth; fire enough for a flint, pearl enough for a swine. 'Tis pretty; it is well.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: Good Master Parson, be so good as read me this letter. It was given me by Costard, and sent me from Don Armado. I beseech you read it.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Fauste precor, gelida quando pecus omne sub umbra Ruminat_- and so forth. Ah, good old Mantuan, I may speak of thee as the traveller doth of Venice: _Venetia, Venetia, Chi non ti vede, non ti pretia._ Old Mantuan, old Mantuan! Who understandeth thee not, loves thee not. Ut, re, sol, la, mi, fa. Under pardon, sir, what are the contents? Or rather as Horace says in his-What, my soul, verses?

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, and very learned.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Let me hear a staff, a stanze, a verse, _Lege, domine_.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: _If love make me forsworn, how shall I swear to love? Ah, never faith could hold, if not to beauty vowed. Though to myself forsworn, to thee I'll faithful prove. Those thoughts to me were oaks, to thee like osiers bowed. Study his bias leaves, and makes his book thine eyes, Where all those pleasures live that art would comprehend. If knowledge be the mark, to know thee shall suffice. Well learned is that tongue that well can thee commend, All ignorant that soul that sees thee without wonder; Which is to me some praise, that I thy parts admire. Thy eye Jove's lightning bears, thy voice his dreadful thunder, Which, not to anger bent, is music and sweet fire. Celestial as thou art, O, pardon love this wrong, That sings heaven's praise with such an earthly tongue._

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: You find not the apostrophus, and so miss the accent. Let me supervise the canzonet.  Here are only numbers ratified, but, for the elegancy, facility, and golden cadence of poesy, _caret_. Ovidius Naso was the man. And why indeed "Naso," but for smelling out the odoriferous flowers of fancy, the jerks of invention? _Imitari_ is nothing: so doth the hound his master, the ape his keeper, the tired horse his rider. But, damosella virgin, was this directed to you?

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, from one Monsieur Berowne, one of the strange queen's lords.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: I will overglance the superscript: _To the snow-white hand of the most beauteous Lady Rosaline._ I will look again on the intellect of the letter, for the nomination of the party writing to the person written unto: _Your Ladyship's in all desired employment, Berowne._ Sir Nathaniel, this Berowne is one of the votaries with the King, and here he hath framed a letter to a sequent of the stranger queen's, which accidentally, or by the way of progression, hath miscarried. Trip and go, my sweet, deliver this paper into the royal hand of the King. It may concern much. Stay not thy compliment. I forgive thy duty. Adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: Good Costard, go with me. Sir, God save your life.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Have with thee, my girl.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Sir, you have done this in the fear of God, very religiously; and, as a certain Father saith-

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Sir, tell not me of the Father, I do fear colourable colours. But to return to the verses: did they please you, Sir Nathaniel?

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Marvellous well for the pen.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: I do dine today at the father's of a certain pupil of mine, where if, before repast, it shall please you to gratify the table with a grace, I will, on my privilege I have with the parents of the foresaid child or pupil, undertake your _ben venuto;_ where I will prove those verses to be very unlearned, neither savouring of poetry, wit, nor invention. I beseech your society.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: And thank you too; for society, saith the text, is the happiness of life.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: And certes, the text most infallibly concludes it.  Sir, I do invite you too. You shall not say me nay. _Pauca verba_. Away! The gentles are at their game, and we will to our recreation.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: The King, he is hunting the deer; I am coursing myself. They have pitched a toil; I am toiling in a pitch, pitch that defiles. Defile! A foul word! Well, set thee down, sorrow, for so they say the fool said, and so say I, and I the fool. Well proved, wit! By the Lord, this love is as mad as Ajax. It kills sheep, it kills me, I a sheep. Well proved again, o' my side! I will not love; if I do, hang me! I' faith, I will not. O, but her eye! By this light, but for her eye, I would not love her; yes, for her two eyes. Well, I do nothing in the world but lie, and lie in my throat. By heaven, I do love, and it hath taught me to rhyme, and to be melancholy. And here is part of my rhyme, and here my melancholy. Well, she hath one o' my sonnets already. The clown bore it, the fool sent it, and the lady hath it. Sweet clown, sweeter fool, sweetest lady! By the world, I would not care a pin if the other three were in. Here comes one with a paper. God give him grace to groan!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Ay me!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Shot, by heaven! Proceed, sweet Cupid, thou hast thumped him with thy birdbolt under the left pap. In faith, secrets!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: [_So sweet a kiss the golden sun gives not To those fresh morning drops upon the rose, As thy eye-beams, when their fresh rays have smote The night of dew that on my cheeks down flows. Nor shines the silver moon one half so bright Through the transparent bosom of the deep As doth thy face, through tears of mine give light. Thou shin'st in every tear that I do weep. No drop but as a coach doth carry thee; So ridest thou triumphing in my woe. Do but behold the tears that swell in me, And they thy glory through my grief will show. But do not love thyself; then thou wilt keep My tears for glasses, and still make me weep. O queen of queens, how far dost thou excel No thought can think, nor tongue of mortal tell._ How shall she know my griefs? I'll drop the paper. Sweet leaves, shade folly. Who is he comes here? What, Longaville, and reading! Listen, ear.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Now, in thy likeness, one more fool appear!

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Ay me! I am forsworn.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Why, he comes in like a perjure, wearing papers.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: In love, I hope. Sweet fellowship in shame.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: One drunkard loves another of the name.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Am I the first that have been perjured so?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I could put thee in comfort: not by two that I know. Thou makest the triumviry, the corner-cap of society, The shape of love's Tyburn, that hangs up simplicity.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: I fear these stubborn lines lack power to move. O sweet Maria, empress of my love, These numbers will I tear, and write in prose.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: O, rhymes are guards on wanton Cupid's hose. Disfigure not his shop.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: This same shall go. _Did not the heavenly rhetoric of thine eye, 'Gainst whom the world cannot hold argument, Persuade my heart to this false perjury? Vows for thee broke deserve not punishment. A woman I forswore, but I will prove, Thou being a goddess, I forswore not thee. My vow was earthly, thou a heavenly love; Thy grace being gained, cures all disgrace in me. Vows are but breath, and breath a vapour is. Then thou, fair sun, which on my earth dost shine, Exhal'st this vapour-vow; in thee it is. If broken then, it is no fault of mine; If by me broke, what fool is not so wise To lose an oath to win a paradise?_

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: This is the liver vein, which makes flesh a deity, A green goose a goddess. Pure, pure idolatry. God amend us, God amend! We are much out o' th' way.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: By whom shall I send this?-Company! Stay.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: All hid, all hid, an old infant play. Like a demigod here sit I in the sky, And wretched fools' secrets heedfully o'er-eye. More sacks to the mill. O heavens, I have my wish. Dumaine transformed! Four woodcocks in a dish!

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: O most divine Kate!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: O most profane coxcomb!

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: By heaven, the wonder in a mortal eye!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: By earth, she is but corporal. There you lie.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Her amber hairs for foul hath amber quoted.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: An amber-coloured raven was well noted.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: As upright as the cedar.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Stoop, I say. Her shoulder is with child.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: As fair as day.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Ay, as some days, but then no sun must shine.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: O, that I had my wish!

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: And I had mine!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: And I mine too, good Lord!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Amen, so I had mine. Is not that a good word?

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: I would forget her; but a fever she Reigns in my blood, and will remembered be.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: A fever in your blood? Why, then incision Would let her out in saucers. Sweet misprision!

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Once more I'll read the ode that I have writ.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Once more I'll mark how love can vary wit.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: _On a day-alack the day!- Love, whose month is ever May, Spied a blossom passing fair Playing in the wanton air. Through the velvet leaves the wind, All unseen, can passage find; That the lover, sick to death, Wished himself the heaven's breath. "Air," quoth he, "thy cheeks may blow; Air, would I might triumph so!" But, alack, my hand is sworn Ne'er to pluck thee from thy thorn. Vow, alack, for youth unmeet, Youth so apt to pluck a sweet. Do not call it sin in me, That I am forsworn for thee; Thou for whom Jove would swear Juno but an Ethiope were, And deny himself for Jove, Turning mortal for thy love._ This will I send, and something else more plain, That shall express my true love's fasting pain. O, would the King, Berowne and Longaville Were lovers too! Ill, to example ill, Would from my forehead wipe a perjured note, For none offend where all alike do dote.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Dumaine, thy love is far from charity, That in love's grief desir'st society. You may look pale, but I should blush, I know, To be o'erheard and taken napping so.
