dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Come, sir, you blush. As his, your case is such. You chide at him, offending twice as much. You do not love Maria? Longaville Did never sonnet for her sake compile, Nor never lay his wreathed arms athwart His loving bosom to keep down his heart. I have been closely shrouded in this bush, And marked you both, and for you both did blush. I heard your guilty rhymes, observed your fashion, Saw sighs reek from you, noted well your passion. "Ay, me!" says one. "O Jove!" the other cries. One, her hairs were gold; crystal the other's eyes.  You would for paradise break faith and troth;  And Jove, for your love would infringe an oath. What will Berowne say when that he shall hear Faith infringed which such zeal did swear? How will he scorn, how will he spend his wit! How will he triumph, leap, and laugh at it! For all the wealth that ever I did see, I would not have him know so much by me.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Now step I forth to whip hypocrisy. Ah, good my liege, I pray thee pardon me. Good heart, what grace hast thou thus to reprove These worms for loving, that art most in love? Your eyes do make no coaches; in your tears There is no certain princess that appears. You'll not be perjured, 'tis a hateful thing: Tush, none but minstrels like of sonneting! But are you not ashamed? Nay, are you not, All three of you, to be thus much o'ershot? You found his mote, the King your mote did see; But I a beam do find in each of three. O, what a scene of foolery have I seen, Of sighs, of groans, of sorrow, and of teen! O me, with what strict patience have I sat, To see a king transformed to a gnat! To see great Hercules whipping a gig, And profound Solomon to tune a jig, And Nestor play at push-pin with the boys, And critic Timon laugh at idle toys. Where lies thy grief, O, tell me, good Dumaine? And, gentle Longaville, where lies thy pain? And where my liege's? All about the breast? A caudle, ho!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Too bitter is thy jest. Are we betrayed thus to thy over-view?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Not you to me, but I betrayed by you. I that am honest, I that hold it sin To break the vow I am engaged in. I am betrayed by keeping company With men like you, men of inconstancy. When shall you see me write a thing in rhyme? Or groan for Joan? Or spend a minute's time In pruning me? When shall you hear that I Will praise a hand, a foot, a face, an eye, A gait, a state, a brow, a breast, a waist, A leg, a limb-

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Soft! Whither away so fast? A true man, or a thief, that gallops so?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I post from love. Good lover, let me go.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: God bless the King!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What present hast thou there?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Some certain treason.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What makes treason here?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Nay, it makes nothing, sir.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: If it mar nothing neither, The treason and you go in peace away together.

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: I beseech your Grace, let this letter be read. Our person misdoubts it; 'twas treason, he said.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Berowne, read it over. Where hadst thou it?

dialogues.speaker: Jaquenetta
dialogues.line: Of Costard.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Where hadst thou it?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Of Dun Adramadio, Dun Adramadio.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: How now, what is in you? Why dost thou tear it?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: A toy, my liege, a toy. Your Grace needs not fear it.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: It did move him to passion, and therefore let's hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: It is Berowne's writing, and here is his name.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Ah, you whoreson loggerhead, you were born to do me shame. Guilty, my lord, guilty. I confess, I confess.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: That you three fools lacked me fool to make up the mess. He, he, and you-and you, my liege-and I Are pick-purses in love, and we deserve to die. O, dismiss this audience, and I shall tell you more.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Now the number is even.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: True, true, we are four. Will these turtles be gone?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Hence, sirs, away!

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Walk aside the true folk, and let the traitors stay.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Sweet lords, sweet lovers, O, let us embrace! As true we are as flesh and blood can be. The sea will ebb and flow, heaven show his face; Young blood doth not obey an old decree. We cannot cross the cause why we were born; Therefore of all hands must we be forsworn.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What, did these rent lines show some love of thine?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: "Did they?" quoth you? Who sees the heavenly Rosaline That, like a rude and savage man of Ind, At the first op'ning of the gorgeous east, Bows not his vassal head and, strucken blind, Kisses the base ground with obedient breast? What peremptory eagle-sighted eye Dares look upon the heaven of her brow That is not blinded by her majesty?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What zeal, what fury hath inspired thee now? My love, her mistress, is a gracious moon; She, an attending star, scarce seen a light.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: My eyes are then no eyes, nor I Berowne. O, but for my love, day would turn to night! Of all complexions the culled sovereignty Do meet as at a fair in her fair cheek, Where several worthies make one dignity, Where nothing wants that want itself doth seek. Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues- Fie, painted rhetoric! O, she needs it not. To things of sale a seller's praise belongs. She passes praise; then praise too short doth blot. A withered hermit, five-score winters worn, Might shake off fifty, looking in her eye. Beauty doth varnish age, as if new born, And gives the crutch the cradle's infancy. O, 'tis the sun that maketh all things shine!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: By heaven, thy love is black as ebony.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Is ebony like her? O word divine! A wife of such wood were felicity. O, who can give an oath? Where is a book? That I may swear beauty doth beauty lack If that she learn not of her eye to look. No face is fair that is not full so black.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: O paradox! Black is the badge of hell, The hue of dungeons and the school of night; And beauty's crest becomes the heavens well.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Devils soonest tempt, resembling spirits of light. O, if in black my lady's brows be decked, It mourns that painting and usurping hair Should ravish doters with a false aspect; And therefore is she born to make black fair. Her favour turns the fashion of the days, For native blood is counted painting now; And therefore red, that would avoid dispraise, Paints itself black, to imitate her brow.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: To look like her are chimney-sweepers black.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: And since her time are colliers counted bright.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: And Ethiopes of their sweet complexion crack.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Dark needs no candles now, for dark is light.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Your mistresses dare never come in rain, For fear their colours should be washed away.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: 'Twere good yours did; for, sir, to tell you plain, I'll find a fairer face not washed today.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I'll prove her fair, or talk till doomsday here.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: No devil will fright thee then so much as she.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: I never knew man hold vile stuff so dear.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Look, here's thy love, my foot and her face see.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: O, if the streets were paved with thine eyes, Her feet were much too dainty for such tread.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: O vile! Then, as she goes, what upward lies The street should see as she walked over head.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: But what of this? Are we not all in love?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Nothing so sure, and thereby all forsworn.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Then leave this chat, and, good Berowne, now prove Our loving lawful, and our faith not torn.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, there; some flattery for this evil.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: O, some authority how to proceed. Some tricks, some quillets, how to cheat the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Some salve for perjury.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: O, 'tis more than need. Have at you, then, affection's men-at-arms. Consider what you first did swear unto: To fast, to study, and to see no woman- Flat treason 'gainst the kingly state of youth. Say, can you fast? Your stomachs are too young, And abstinence engenders maladies. O, we have made a vow to study, lords, And in that vow we have forsworn our books; For when would you, my liege, or you, or you, In leaden contemplation have found out Such fiery numbers as the prompting eyes Of beauty's tutors have enriched you with? Other slow arts entirely keep the brain, And therefore, finding barren practisers, Scarce show a harvest of their heavy toil; But love, first learned in a lady's eyes, Lives not alone immured in the brain, But with the motion of all elements Courses as swift as thought in every power, And gives to every power a double power, Above their functions and their offices. It adds a precious seeing to the eye. A lover's eyes will gaze an eagle blind. A lover's ear will hear the lowest sound, When the suspicious head of theft is stopped. Love's feeling is more soft and sensible Than are the tender horns of cockled snails. Love's tongue proves dainty Bacchus gross in taste. For valour, is not Love a Hercules, Still climbing trees in the Hesperides? Subtle as Sphinx, as sweet and musical As bright Apollo's lute, strung with his hair. And when Love speaks, the voice of all the gods Make heaven drowsy with the harmony. Never durst poet touch a pen to write Until his ink were tempered with Love's sighs. O, then his lines would ravish savage ears And plant in tyrants mild humility. From women's eyes this doctrine I derive. They sparkle still the right Promethean fire; They are the books, the arts, the academes, That show, contain, and nourish, all the world; Else none at all in aught proves excellent. Then fools you were these women to forswear, Or, keeping what is sworn, you will prove fools. For wisdom's sake, a word that all men love, Or for love's sake, a word that loves all men, Or for men's sake, the authors of these women, Or women's sake, by whom we men are men, Let us once lose our oaths to find ourselves, Or else we lose ourselves to keep our oaths. It is religion to be thus forsworn, For charity itself fulfils the law, And who can sever love from charity?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Saint Cupid, then, and, soldiers, to the field!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Advance your standards, and upon them, lords! Pell-mell, down with them! But be first advised In conflict that you get the sun of them.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Now to plain dealing. Lay these glozes by. Shall we resolve to woo these girls of France?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: And win them too. Therefore let us devise Some entertainment for them in their tents.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: First, from the park let us conduct them thither. Then homeward every man attach the hand Of his fair mistress. In the afternoon We will with some strange pastime solace them, Such as the shortness of the time can shape; For revels, dances, masques, and merry hours Forerun fair Love, strewing her way with flowers.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Away, away! No time shall be omitted That will betime and may by us be fitted.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: _Allons! allons!_ Sowed cockle reaped no corn, And justice always whirls in equal measure. Light wenches may prove plagues to men forsworn; If so, our copper buys no better treasure.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Satis quod sufficit._

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: I praise God for you, sir. Your reasons at dinner have been sharp and sententious, pleasant without scurrility, witty without affection, audacious without impudency, learned without opinion, and strange without heresy. I did converse this _quondam_ day with a companion of the King's, who is intituled, nominated, or called, Don Adriano de Armado.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Novi hominem tanquam te._ His humour is lofty, his discourse peremptory, his tongue filed, his eye ambitious, his gait majestical and his general behaviour vain, ridiculous, and thrasonical. He is too picked, too spruce, too affected, too odd, as it were, too peregrinate, as I may call it.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: A most singular and choice epithet.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: He draweth out the thread of his verbosity finer than the staple of his argument. I abhor such fanatical phantasimes, such insociable and point-devise companions, such rackers of orthography, as to speak "dout" _sine_ "b", when he should say "doubt", "det" when he should pronounce "debt"-_d, e, b, t_, not _d, e, t_. He clepeth a calf "cauf", half "hauf"; neighbour _vocatur_ "nebour", neigh abbreviated "ne". This is abhominable, which he would call "abominable". It insinuateth me of insanie. _Ne intelligis, domine?_ To make frantic, lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: _Laus Deo, bone intelligo._

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Bone? Bone_ for _bene?_ Priscian a little scratched; 'twill serve.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: _Videsne quis venit?_

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Video, et gaudeo._

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: _Chirrah!_

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Quare_ "chirrah", not "sirrah"?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Men of peace, well encountered.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Most military sir, salutation.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: They have been at a great feast of languages and stolen the scraps.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: O, they have lived long on the almsbasket of words. I marvel thy master hath not eaten thee for a word, for thou art not so long by the head as _honorificabilitudinitatibus_. Thou art easier swallowed than a flap-dragon.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Peace! The peal begins.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Monsieur, are you not lettered?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Yes, yes, he teaches boys the hornbook. What is _a, b_, spelt backward with the horn on his head?

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Ba, pueritia_, with a horn added.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: _Ba_, most silly sheep with a horn. You hear his learning.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Quis, quis_, thou consonant?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: The third of the five vowels, if you repeat them; or the fifth, if I.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: I will repeat them: _a, e, i_-

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: The sheep. The other two concludes it: _o, u_.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Now, by the salt wave of the Mediterraneum, a sweet touch, a quick venue of wit! Snip, snap, quick and home! It rejoiceth my intellect. True wit!

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Offered by a child to an old man-which is wit-old.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: What is the figure? What is the figure?

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Horns.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Thou disputes like an infant. Go whip thy gig.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Lend me your horn to make one, and I will whip about your infamy _unum cita_. A gig of a cuckold's horn.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: An I had but one penny in the world, thou shouldst have it to buy gingerbread. Hold, there is the very remuneration I had of thy master, thou halfpenny purse of wit, thou pigeon-egg of discretion. O, an the heavens were so pleased that thou wert but my bastard, what a joyful father wouldst thou make me! Go to, thou hast it _ad dunghill_, at the fingers' ends, as they say.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: O, I smell false Latin! _Dunghill_ for _unguem_.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Arts-man, preambulate. We will be singuled from the barbarous. Do you not educate youth at the charge-house on the top of the mountain?

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Or _mons_, the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: At your sweet pleasure, for the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: I do, _sans question_.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sir, it is the King's most sweet pleasure and affection to congratulate the Princess at her pavilion in the posteriors of this day, which the rude multitude call the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: The posterior of the day, most generous sir, is liable, congruent, and measurable for the afternoon. The word is well culled, chose, sweet, and apt, I do assure you, sir, I do assure.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sir, the King is a noble gentleman, and my familiar, I do assure ye, very good friend. For what is inward between us, let it pass. I do beseech thee, remember thy courtesy; I beseech thee, apparel thy head. And among other importunate and most serious designs, and of great import indeed, too-but let that pass. For I must tell thee it will please his Grace, by the world, sometime to lean upon my poor shoulder and with his royal finger thus dally with my excrement, with my mustachio. But, sweet heart, let that pass. By the world, I recount no fable! Some certain special honours it pleaseth his greatness to impart to Armado, a soldier, a man of travel, that hath seen the world. But let that pass. The very all of all is-but, sweet heart, I do implore secrecy-that the King would have me present the Princess, sweet chuck, with some delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antic, or firework. Now, understanding that the curate and your sweet self are good at such eruptions and sudden breaking-out of mirth, as it were, I have acquainted you withal, to the end to crave your assistance.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Sir, you shall present before her the Nine Worthies. Sir Nathaniel, as concerning some entertainment of time, some show in the posterior of this day, to be rendered by our assistance, the King's command, and this most gallant, illustrate, and learned gentleman, before the Princess, I say, none so fit as to present the Nine Worthies.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: Where will you find men worthy enough to present them?

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Joshua, yourself; myself; and this gallant gentleman, Judas Maccabaeus. This swain, because of his great limb or joint, shall pass Pompey the Great; the page, Hercules.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Pardon, sir; error. He is not quantity enough for that Worthy's thumb; he is not so big as the end of his club.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Shall I have audience? He shall present Hercules in minority. His enter and exit shall be strangling a snake; and I will have an apology for that purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: An excellent device! So, if any of the audience hiss, you may cry "Well done, Hercules, now thou crushest the snake!" That is the way to make an offence gracious, though few have the grace to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: For the rest of the Worthies?

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: I will play three myself.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Thrice-worthy gentleman!

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Shall I tell you a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: We attend.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: We will have, if this fadge not, an antic. I beseech you, follow.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Via_, goodman Dull! Thou has spoken no word all this while.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: Nor understood none neither, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Allons!_ we will employ thee.

dialogues.speaker: Dull
dialogues.line: I'll make one in a dance, or so; or I will play on the tabor to the Worthies, and let them dance the hay.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Most dull, honest Dull! To our sport, away.

scenes.location: The same. Before the Princess's pavilion

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Sweet hearts, we shall be rich ere we depart, If fairings come thus plentifully in. A lady walled about with diamonds! Look you what I have from the loving King.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Madam, came nothing else along with that?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Nothing but this? Yes, as much love in rhyme As would be crammed up in a sheet of paper Writ o' both sides the leaf, margent and all, That he was fain to seal on Cupid's name.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: That was the way to make his godhead wax, For he hath been five thousand years a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Ay, and a shrewd unhappy gallows too.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: You'll ne'er be friends with him. He killed your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: He made her melancholy, sad, and heavy; And so she died. Had she been light, like you, Of such a merry, nimble, stirring spirit, She might ha' been a grandam ere she died. And so may you, for a light heart lives long.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: What's your dark meaning, mouse, of this light word?

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: A light condition in a beauty dark.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: We need more light to find your meaning out.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: You'll mar the light by taking it in snuff; Therefore I'll darkly end the argument.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Look what you do, you do it still i' th' dark.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: So do not you, for you are a light wench.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Indeed, I weigh not you, and therefore light.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: You weigh me not? O, that's you care not for me.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Great reason, for past cure is still past care.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Well bandied both; a set of wit well played. But, Rosaline, you have a favour too. Who sent it? And what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: I would you knew. An if my face were but as fair as yours, My favour were as great. Be witness this. Nay, I have verses too, I thank Berowne; The numbers true, and, were the numbering too, I were the fairest goddess on the ground. I am compared to twenty thousand fairs. O, he hath drawn my picture in his letter.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Anything like?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Much in the letters, nothing in the praise.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Beauteous as ink: a good conclusion.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Fair as a text B in a copy-book.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: 'Ware pencils, how! Let me not die your debtor, My red dominical, my golden letter. O, that your face were not so full of O's!

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: A pox of that jest! And beshrew all shrews. But, Katharine, what was sent to you from fair Dumaine?

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Madam, this glove.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Did he not send you twain?

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Yes, madam, and moreover, Some thousand verses of a faithful lover. A huge translation of hypocrisy, Vilely compiled, profound simplicity.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: This, and these pearls, to me sent Longaville. The letter is too long by half a mile.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: I think no less. Dost thou not wish in heart The chain were longer and the letter short?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Ay, or I would these hands might never part.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: We are wise girls to mock our lovers so.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: They are worse fools to purchase mocking so. That same Berowne I'll torture ere I go. O that I knew he were but in by th' week! How I would make him fawn, and beg, and seek, And wait the season, and observe the times, And spend his prodigal wits in bootless rhymes, And shape his service wholly to my hests, And make him proud to make me proud that jests! So pair-taunt-like would I o'ersway his state, That he should be my fool, and I his fate.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: None are so surely caught, when they are catched, As wit turned fool. Folly, in wisdom hatched, Hath wisdom's warrant and the help of school And wit's own grace to grace a learned fool.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: The blood of youth burns not with such excess As gravity's revolt to wantonness.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Folly in fools bears not so strong a note As fool'ry in the wise when wit doth dote, Since all the power thereof it doth apply To prove, by wit, worth in simplicity.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Here comes Boyet, and mirth is in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: O, I am stabbed with laughter! Where's her Grace?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Thy news, Boyet?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Prepare, madam, prepare! Arm, wenches, arm! Encounters mounted are Against your peace. Love doth approach disguised, Armed in arguments. You'll be surprised. Muster your wits, stand in your own defence, Or hide your heads like cowards, and fly hence.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Saint Denis to Saint Cupid! What are they That charge their breath against us? Say, scout, say.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Under the cool shade of a sycamore I thought to close mine eyes some half an hour, When, lo, to interrupt my purposed rest, Toward that shade I might behold addressed The King and his companions. Warily I stole into a neighbour thicket by, And overheard what you shall overhear: That, by and by, disguised they will be here. Their herald is a pretty knavish page That well by heart hath conned his embassage. Action and accent did they teach him there: "Thus must thou speak," and "thus thy body bear." And ever and anon they made a doubt Presence majestical would put him out; "For," quoth the King, "an angel shalt thou see; Yet fear not thou, but speak audaciously." The boy replied "An angel is not evil; I should have feared her had she been a devil." With that all laughed and clapped him on the shoulder, Making the bold wag by their praises bolder. One rubbed his elbow thus, and fleered, and swore A better speech was never spoke before. Another with his finger and his thumb Cried "_Via_, we will do 't, come what will come." The third he capered, and cried "All goes well!" The fourth turned on the toe, and down he fell. With that they all did tumble on the ground, With such a zealous laughter, so profound, That in this spleen ridiculous appears, To check their folly, passion's solemn tears.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: But what, but what, come they to visit us?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: They do, they do, and are apparelled thus, Like Muscovites, or Russians, as I guess. Their purpose is to parley, court, and dance, And every one his love-feat will advance Unto his several mistress, which they'll know By favours several which they did bestow.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: And will they so? The gallants shall be tasked; For, ladies, we will every one be masked, And not a man of them shall have the grace, Despite of suit, to see a lady's face. Hold, Rosaline, this favour thou shalt wear, And then the King will court thee for his dear. Hold, take thou this, my sweet, and give me thine, So shall Berowne take me for Rosaline. And change you favours too; so shall your loves Woo contrary, deceived by these removes.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Come on, then, wear the favours most in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: But in this changing, what is your intent?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: The effect of my intent is to cross theirs. They do it but in mocking merriment, And mock for mock is only my intent. Their several counsels they unbosom shall To loves mistook, and so be mocked withal Upon the next occasion that we meet, With visages displayed to talk and greet.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: But shall we dance, if they desire us to't?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: No, to the death we will not move a foot, Nor to their penned speech render we no grace, But while 'tis spoke each turn away her face.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Why, that contempt will kill the speaker's heart, And quite divorce his memory from his part.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Therefore I do it, and I make no doubt The rest will ne'er come in, if he be out. There's no such sport as sport by sport o'erthrown, To make theirs ours and ours none but our own. So shall we stay, mocking intended game, And they, well mocked, depart away with shame.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: The trumpet sounds. Be masked; the maskers come. Longaville and Dumaine disguised.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: _All hail, the richest beauties on the earth!_

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Beauties no richer than rich taffeta.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: _A holy parcel of the fairest dames_ _That ever turned their_-backs-_to mortal views!_

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: _Their eyes_, villain, _their eyes._

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: _That ever turned their eyes to mortal views. Out_-

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: True; out indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: _Out of your favours, heavenly spirits, vouchsafe Not to behold_-

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: _Once to behold_, rogue!

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: _Once to behold with your sun-beamed eyes- With your sun-beamed eyes_-

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: They will not answer to that epithet. You were best call it "daughter-beamed eyes".

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: They do not mark me, and that brings me out.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Is this your perfectness? Be gone, you rogue!

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: What would these strangers? Know their minds, Boyet. If they do speak our language, 'tis our will That some plain man recount their purposes. Know what they would.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: What would you with the Princess?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: What would they, say they?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Nothing but peace and gentle visitation.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Why, that they have, and bid them so be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: She says you have it, and you may be gone.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Say to her we have measured many miles To tread a measure with her on this grass.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: They say that they have measured many a mile To tread a measure with you on this grass.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: It is not so. Ask them how many inches Is in one mile? If they have measured many, The measure then of one is easily told.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: If to come hither you have measured miles, And many miles, the Princess bids you tell How many inches doth fill up one mile.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Tell her we measure them by weary steps.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: She hears herself.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: How many weary steps Of many weary miles you have o'ergone Are numbered in the travel of one mile?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: We number nothing that we spend for you. Our duty is so rich, so infinite, That we may do it still without account. Vouchsafe to show the sunshine of your face, That we, like savages, may worship it.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: My face is but a moon, and clouded too.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Blessed are clouds, to do as such clouds do! Vouchsafe, bright moon, and these thy stars, to shine, Those clouds removed, upon our watery eyne.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: O vain petitioner! Beg a greater matter! Thou now requests but moonshine in the water.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Then in our measure do but vouchsafe one change. Thou bidd'st me beg; this begging is not strange.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Play, music, then! Nay, you must do it soon. Not yet? No dance! Thus change I like the moon.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Will you not dance? How come you thus estranged?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: You took the moon at full, but now she's changed.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Yet still she is the moon, and I the man. The music plays, vouchsafe some motion to it.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Our ears vouchsafe it.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: But your legs should do it.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Since you are strangers and come here by chance, We'll not be nice. Take hands. We will not dance.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Why take we hands then?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Only to part friends. Curtsy, sweet hearts, and so the measure ends.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: More measure of this measure! Be not nice.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: We can afford no more at such a price.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Price you yourselves? What buys your company?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Your absence only.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: That can never be.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Then cannot we be bought. And so adieu- Twice to your visor, and half once to you!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: If you deny to dance, let's hold more chat.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: In private then.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I am best pleased with that.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: White-handed mistress, one sweet word with thee.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Honey, and milk, and sugar: there is three.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Nay, then, two treys, an if you grow so nice, Metheglin, wort, and malmsey. Well run, dice! There's half a dozen sweets.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Seventh sweet, adieu. Since you can cog, I'll play no more with you.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: One word in secret.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Let it not be sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Thou griev'st my gall.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Gall! Bitter.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Therefore meet.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Will you vouchsafe with me to change a word?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Name it.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Fair lady-

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Say you so? Fair lord! Take that for your "fair lady".

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Please it you, As much in private, and I'll bid adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: What, was your visor made without a tongue?

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: I know the reason, lady, why you ask.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: O, for your reason! Quickly, sir, I long.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: You have a double tongue within your mask, And would afford my speechless visor half.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: "Veal", quoth the Dutchman. Is not veal a calf?

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: A calf, fair lady?

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: No, a fair lord calf.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Let's part the word.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: No, I'll not be your half. Take all and wean it; it may prove an ox.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Look how you butt yourself in these sharp mocks. Will you give horns, chaste lady? Do not so.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Then die a calf before your horns do grow.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: One word in private with you ere I die.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Bleat softly, then; the butcher hears you cry.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: The tongues of mocking wenches are as keen As is the razor's edge invisible, Cutting a smaller hair than may be seen; Above the sense of sense, so sensible Seemeth their conference. Their conceits have wings Fleeter than arrows, bullets, wind, thought, swifter things.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Not one word more, my maids; break off, break off.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: By heaven, all dry-beaten with pure scoff!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Farewell, mad wenches. You have simple wits.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Twenty adieus, my frozen Muscovites. Are these the breed of wits so wondered at?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Tapers they are, with your sweet breaths puffed out.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Well-liking wits they have; gross, gross; fat, fat.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: O poverty in wit, kingly-poor flout! Will they not, think you, hang themselves tonight? Or ever but in vizors show their faces? This pert Berowne was out of countenance quite.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: They were all in lamentable cases. The King was weeping-ripe for a good word.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Berowne did swear himself out of all suit.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Dumaine was at my service, and his sword. "_Non point_," quoth I; my servant straight was mute.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Lord Longaville said I came o'er his heart; And trow you what he called me?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Qualm, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Yes, in good faith.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Go, sickness as thou art!

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Well, better wits have worn plain statute-caps. But will you hear? The King is my love sworn.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: And quick Berowne hath plighted faith to me.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: And Longaville was for my service born.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Dumaine is mine as sure as bark on tree.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Madam, and pretty mistresses, give ear. Immediately they will again be here In their own shapes, for it can never be They will digest this harsh indignity.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Will they return?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: They will, they will, God knows, And leap for joy, though they are lame with blows. Therefore, change favours and, when they repair, Blow like sweet roses in this summer air.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: How "blow"? How "blow"? Speak to be understood.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Fair ladies masked are roses in their bud. Dismasked, their damask sweet commixture shown, Are angels vailing clouds, or roses blown.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Avaunt, perplexity! What shall we do If they return in their own shapes to woo?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Good madam, if by me you'll be advised, Let's mock them still, as well known as disguised. Let us complain to them what fools were here, Disguised like Muscovites in shapeless gear; And wonder what they were, and to what end Their shallow shows and prologue vilely penned, And their rough carriage so ridiculous, Should be presented at our tent to us.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Ladies, withdraw. The gallants are at hand.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Whip to our tents, as roes run o'er the land.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Fair sir, God save you. Where's the Princess?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Gone to her tent. Please it your Majesty Command me any service to her thither?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: That she vouchsafe me audience for one word.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: I will; and so will she, I know, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: This fellow pecks up wit as pigeons peas And utters it again when God doth please. He is wit's pedlar, and retails his wares At wakes and wassails, meetings, markets, fairs; And we that sell by gross, the Lord doth know, Have not the grace to grace it with such show. This gallant pins the wenches on his sleeve. Had he been Adam, he had tempted Eve. He can carve too, and lisp. Why, this is he That kissed his hand away in courtesy. This is the ape of form, Monsieur the Nice, That, when he plays at tables, chides the dice In honourable terms. Nay, he can sing A mean most meanly; and in ushering Mend him who can. The ladies call him sweet. The stairs, as he treads on them, kiss his feet. This is the flower that smiles on everyone, To show his teeth as white as whale's bone; And consciences that will not die in debt Pay him the due of "honey-tongued Boyet".

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: A blister on his sweet tongue, with my heart, That put Armado's page out of his part!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: See where it comes! Behaviour, what wert thou Till this man showed thee, and what art thou now?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: All hail, sweet madam, and fair time of day.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: "Fair" in "all hail" is foul, as I conceive.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Construe my speeches better, if you may.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Then wish me better. I will give you leave.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: We came to visit you, and purpose now To lead you to our court. Vouchsafe it then.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: This field shall hold me, and so hold your vow. Nor God nor I delights in perjured men.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Rebuke me not for that which you provoke. The virtue of your eye must break my oath.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: You nickname virtue: "vice" you should have spoke; For virtue's office never breaks men's troth. Now by my maiden honour, yet as pure As the unsullied lily, I protest, A world of torments though I should endure, I would not yield to be your house's guest, So much I hate a breaking cause to be Of heavenly oaths, vowed with integrity.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: O, you have lived in desolation here, Unseen, unvisited, much to our shame.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Not so, my lord. It is not so, I swear. We have had pastimes here and pleasant game. A mess of Russians left us but of late.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: How, madam? Russians?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Ay, in truth, my lord. Trim gallants, full of courtship and of state.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Madam, speak true. It is not so, my lord. My lady, to the manner of the days, In courtesy gives undeserving praise. We four indeed confronted were with four In Russian habit. Here they stayed an hour And talked apace; and in that hour, my lord, They did not bless us with one happy word. I dare not call them fools; but this I think, When they are thirsty, fools would fain have drink.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: This jest is dry to me. My gentle sweet, Your wit makes wise things foolish. When we greet, With eyes' best seeing, heaven's fiery eye, By light we lose light. Your capacity Is of that nature that to your huge store Wise things seem foolish and rich things but poor.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: This proves you wise and rich, for in my eye-

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I am a fool, and full of poverty.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: But that you take what doth to you belong, It were a fault to snatch words from my tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: O, I am yours, and all that I possess.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: All the fool mine?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: I cannot give you less.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Which of the visors was it that you wore?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Where, when, what visor? Why demand you this?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: There, then, that visor; that superfluous case That hid the worse and showed the better face.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: We are descried. They'll mock us now downright.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Let us confess and turn it to a jest.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Amazed, my lord? Why looks your Highness sad?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Help! Hold his brows! He'll swoon. Why look you pale? Seasick, I think, coming from Muscovy.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Thus pour the stars down plagues for perjury. Can any face of brass hold longer out? Here stand I, lady; dart thy skill at me. Bruise me with scorn, confound me with a flout, Thrust thy sharp wit quite through my ignorance, Cut me to pieces with thy keen conceit, And I will wish thee never more to dance, Nor never more in Russian habit wait. O, never will I trust to speeches penned, Nor to the motion of a school-boy's tongue, Nor never come in visor to my friend, Nor woo in rhyme like a blind harper's song. Taffeta phrases, silken terms precise, Three-piled hyperboles, spruce affectation, Figures pedantical: these summer flies Have blown me full of maggot ostentation. I do forswear them, and I here protest, By this white glove-how white the hand, God knows!- Henceforth my wooing mind shall be expressed In russet yeas and honest kersey noes. And, to begin: wench, so God help me, law, My love to thee is sound, _sans_ crack or flaw.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: _Sans_ "_sans_," I pray you.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Yet I have a trick Of the old rage. Bear with me, I am sick; I'll leave it by degrees. Soft, let us see: Write "Lord have mercy on us" on those three. They are infected; in their hearts it lies; They have the plague, and caught it of your eyes. These lords are visited. You are not free, For the Lord's tokens on you do I see.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: No, they are free that gave these tokens to us.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Our states are forfeit. Seek not to undo us.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: It is not so. For how can this be true, That you stand forfeit, being those that sue?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Peace! for I will not have to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Nor shall not, if I do as I intend.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Speak for yourselves. My wit is at an end.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Teach us, sweet madam, for our rude transgression Some fair excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: The fairest is confession. Were not you here but even now, disguised?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Madam, I was.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: And were you well advised?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I was, fair madam.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: When you then were here, What did you whisper in your lady's ear?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: That more than all the world I did respect her.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: When she shall challenge this, you will reject her.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Upon mine honour, no.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Peace, peace, forbear! Your oath once broke, you force not to forswear.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Despise me when I break this oath of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: I will; and therefore keep it. Rosaline, What did the Russian whisper in your ear?

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Madam, he swore that he did hold me dear As precious eyesight, and did value me Above this world; adding thereto, moreover, That he would wed me, or else die my lover.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: God give thee joy of him! The noble lord Most honourably doth uphold his word.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What mean you, madam? By my life, my troth, I never swore this lady such an oath.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: By heaven, you did! And to confirm it plain, You gave me this. But take it, sir, again.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: My faith and this the Princess I did give. I knew her by this jewel on her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Pardon me, sir, this jewel did she wear, And Lord Berowne, I thank him, is my dear. What, will you have me, or your pearl again?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Neither of either; I remit both twain. I see the trick on't. Here was a consent, Knowing aforehand of our merriment, To dash it like a Christmas comedy. Some carry-tale, some please-man, some slight zany, Some mumble-news, some trencher-knight, some Dick, That smiles his cheek in years and knows the trick To make my lady laugh when she's disposed, Told our intents before; which once disclosed, The ladies did change favours, and then we, Following the signs, wooed but the sign of she. Now, to our perjury to add more terror, We are again forsworn in will and error. Much upon this 'tis.  And might not you Forestall our sport, to make us thus untrue? Do not you know my lady's foot by th' squier, And laugh upon the apple of her eye? And stand between her back, sir, and the fire, Holding a trencher, jesting merrily? You put our page out. Go, you are allowed; Die when you will, a smock shall be your shroud. You leer upon me, do you? There's an eye Wounds like a leaden sword.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Full merrily Hath this brave manage, this career, been run.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Lo, he is tilting straight! Peace! I have done. Welcome, pure wit! Thou part'st a fair fray.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: O Lord, sir, they would know Whether the three Worthies shall come in or no.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: What, are there but three?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: No, sir; but it is vara fine, For every one pursents three.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: And three times thrice is nine.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Not so, sir, under correction, sir, I hope it is not so. You cannot beg us, sir, I can assure you, sir; we know what we know. I hope, sir, three times thrice, sir-

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Is not nine?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Under correction, sir, we know whereuntil it doth amount.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: By Jove, I always took three threes for nine.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: O Lord, sir, it were pity you should get your living by reckoning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: How much is it?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: O Lord, sir, the parties themselves, the actors, sir, will show whereuntil it doth amount. For mine own part, I am, as they say, but to parfect one man in one poor man-Pompion the Great, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Art thou one of the Worthies?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: It pleased them to think me worthy of Pompey the Great. For mine own part, I know not the degree of the Worthy, but I am to stand for him.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Go bid them prepare.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: We will turn it finely off, sir; we will take some care.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Berowne, they will shame us. Let them not approach.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: We are shame-proof, my lord, and 'tis some policy To have one show worse than the King's and his company.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I say they shall not come.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Nay, my good lord, let me o'errule you now. That sport best pleases that doth least know how, Where zeal strives to content, and the contents Die in the zeal of that which it presents; Their form confounded makes most form in mirth, When great things labouring perish in their birth.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: A right description of our sport, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Anointed, I implore so much expense of thy royal sweet breath as will utter a brace of words.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Doth this man serve God?

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Why ask you?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: He speaks not like a man of God his making.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: That is all one, my fair, sweet, honey monarch; for, I protest, the schoolmaster is exceeding fantastical; too, too vain, too, too vain. But we will put it, as they say, to _fortuna de la guerra_. I wish you the peace of mind, most royal couplement!

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Here is like to be a good presence of Worthies. He presents Hector of Troy; the swain, Pompey the Great; the parish curate, Alexander; Armado's page, Hercules; the pedant, Judas Maccabaeus. _And if these four Worthies in their first show thrive, These four will change habits and present the other five._

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: There is five in the first show.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: You are deceived. 'Tis not so.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: The pedant, the braggart, the hedge-priest, the fool, and the boy. Abate throw at novum, and the whole world again Cannot pick out five such, take each one in his vein.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: The ship is under sail, and here she comes amain.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: _I Pompey am_-

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: You lie, you are not he.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: _I Pompey am_-

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: With leopard's head on knee.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Well said, old mocker. I must needs be friends with thee.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: _I Pompey am, Pompey surnamed the Big._

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: The "Great".

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: It is "Great", sir; _Pompey surnamed the Great, That oft in field, with targe and shield, did make my foe to sweat. And travelling along this coast, I here am come by chance, And lay my arms before the legs of this sweet lass of France._ If your ladyship would say, "Thanks, Pompey", I had done.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Great thanks, great Pompey.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: 'Tis not so much worth; but I hope I was perfect. I made a little fault in "Great".

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: My hat to a halfpenny, Pompey proves the best Worthy.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: _When in the world I lived, I was the world's commander; By east, west, north, and south, I spread my conquering might. My scutcheon plain declares that I am Alisander._

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Your nose says, no, you are not; for it stands to right.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Your nose smells "no" in this, most tender-smelling knight.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: The conqueror is dismayed. Proceed, good Alexander.

dialogues.speaker: Nathaniel
dialogues.line: _When in the world I lived, I was the world's commander_-

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Most true; 'tis right. You were so, Alisander.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Pompey the Great-

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Your servant, and Costard.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Take away the conqueror, take away Alisander.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: O sir, you have overthrown Alisander the Conqueror. You will be scraped out of the painted cloth for this. Your lion, that holds his pole-axe sitting on a close-stool, will be given to Ajax. He will be the ninth Worthy. A conqueror, and afeard to speak? Run away for shame, Alisander.  There, an't shall please you, a foolish mild man; an honest man, look you, and soon dashed. He is a marvellous good neighbour, faith, and a very good bowler; but for Alisander, alas you see how 'tis-a little o'erparted. But there are Worthies a-coming will speak their mind in some other sort.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Stand aside, good Pompey.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Great Hercules is presented by this imp, Whose club killed Cerberus, that three-headed_ canus, _And when he was a babe, a child, a shrimp, Thus did he strangle serpents in his_ manus. Quoniam _he seemeth in minority_, Ergo _I come with this apology._ Keep some state in thy exit, and vanish. _Judas I am._-

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: A Judas!

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Not Iscariot, sir. _Judas I am, ycleped Maccabaeus._

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Judas Maccabaeus clipped is plain Judas.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: A kissing traitor. How art thou proved Judas?

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: _Judas I am_-

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: The more shame for you, Judas.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: What mean you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: To make Judas hang himself.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: Begin, sir; you are my elder.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Well followed. Judas was hanged on an elder.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: I will not be put out of countenance.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Because thou hast no face.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: A cittern-head.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: The head of a bodkin.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: A death's face in a ring.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: The face of an old Roman coin, scarce seen.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: The pommel of Caesar's falchion.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: The carved-bone face on a flask.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Saint George's half-cheek in a brooch.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Ay, and in a brooch of lead.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Ay, and worn in the cap of a tooth-drawer. And now forward, for we have put thee in countenance.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: You have put me out of countenance.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: False. We have given thee faces.

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: But you have outfaced them all.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: An thou wert a lion, we would do so.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Therefore, as he is an ass, let him go. And so adieu, sweet Jude. Nay, why dost thou stay?

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: For the latter end of his name.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: For the ass to the Jude? Give it him. Jud-as, away!

dialogues.speaker: Holofernes
dialogues.line: This is not generous, not gentle, not humble.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: A light for Monsieur Judas! It grows dark; he may stumble.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Alas, poor Maccabaeus, how hath he been baited!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Hide thy head, Achilles. Here comes Hector in arms.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Though my mocks come home by me, I will now be merry.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Hector was but a Trojan in respect of this.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: But is this Hector?

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: I think Hector was not so clean-timbered.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: His leg is too big for Hector's.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: More calf, certain.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: No, he is best endued in the small.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: This cannot be Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: He's a god or a painter, for he makes faces.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: _The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty, Gave Hector a gift_-

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: A gilt nutmeg.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: A lemon.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: Stuck with cloves.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: No, cloven.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Peace! _The armipotent Mars, of lances the almighty, Gave Hector a gift, the heir of Ilion; A man so breathed that certain he would fight, yea, From morn till night, out of his pavilion. I am that flower_-

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: That mint.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: That columbine.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sweet Lord Longaville, rein thy tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: I must rather give it the rein, for it runs against Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Ay, and Hector's a greyhound.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: The sweet war-man is dead and rotten. Sweet chucks, beat not the bones of the buried. When he breathed, he was a man. But I will forward with my device.  Sweet royalty, bestow on me the sense of hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Speak, brave Hector; we are much delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I do adore thy sweet Grace's slipper.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Loves her by the foot.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: He may not by the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: _This Hector far surmounted Hannibal. The party is gone_-

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Fellow Hector, she is gone; she is two months on her way.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: What meanest thou?

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Faith, unless you play the honest Trojan, the poor wench is cast away. She's quick; the child brags in her belly already. 'Tis yours.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Dost thou infamonize me among potentates? Thou shalt die.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: Then shall Hector be whipped for Jaquenetta that is quick by him, and hanged for Pompey that is dead by him.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Most rare Pompey!

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: Renowned Pompey!

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Greater than  "Great"! Great, great, great Pompey! Pompey the Huge!

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Hector trembles.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Pompey is moved. More Ates, more Ates! Stir them on, stir them on!

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Hector will challenge him.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Ay, if he have no more man's blood in his belly than will sup a flea.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: By the north pole, I do challenge thee.

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I will not fight with a pole, like a northern man. I'll slash, I'll do it by the sword. I bepray you, let me borrow my arms again.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Room for the incensed Worthies!

dialogues.speaker: Costard
dialogues.line: I'll do it in my shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Most resolute Pompey!

dialogues.speaker: Moth
dialogues.line: Master, let me take you a buttonhole lower. Do you not see Pompey is uncasing for the combat? What mean you? You will lose your reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Gentlemen and soldiers, pardon me. I will not combat in my shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: You may not deny it. Pompey hath made the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sweet bloods, I both may and will.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: What reason have you for 't?

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: The naked truth of it is, I have no shirt. I go woolward for penance.

dialogues.speaker: Boyet
dialogues.line: True, and it was enjoined him in Rome for want of linen; since when, I'll be sworn, he wore none but a dishclout of Jaquenetta's, and that he wears next his heart for a favour. Enter a Messenger, Monsieur Marcadé. MARCADÉ. God save you, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Welcome, Marcadé, But that thou interruptest our merriment. MARCADÉ. I am sorry, madam, for the news I bring Is heavy in my tongue. The King your father-

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Dead, for my life! MARCADÉ. Even so. My tale is told.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Worthies away! The scene begins to cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: For mine own part, I breathe free breath. I have seen the day of wrong through the little hole of discretion, and I will right myself like a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: How fares your Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Boyet, prepare. I will away tonight.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Madam, not so. I do beseech you stay.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Prepare, I say. I thank you, gracious lords, For all your fair endeavours, and entreat, Out of a new-sad soul, that you vouchsafe In your rich wisdom to excuse or hide The liberal opposition of our spirits, If over-boldly we have borne ourselves In the converse of breath; your gentleness Was guilty of it. Farewell, worthy lord! A heavy heart bears not a nimble tongue. Excuse me so, coming too short of thanks For my great suit so easily obtained.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: The extreme parts of time extremely forms All causes to the purpose of his speed, And often at his very loose decides That which long process could not arbitrate. And though the mourning brow of progeny Forbid the smiling courtesy of love The holy suit which fain it would convince, Yet, since love's argument was first on foot, Let not the cloud of sorrow jostle it From what it purposed; since to wail friends lost Is not by much so wholesome-profitable As to rejoice at friends but newly found.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: I understand you not. My griefs are double.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Honest plain words best pierce the ear of grief; And by these badges understand the King. For your fair sakes have we neglected time, Played foul play with our oaths. Your beauty, ladies, Hath much deformed us, fashioning our humours Even to the opposed end of our intents; And what in us hath seemed ridiculous- As love is full of unbefitting strains, All wanton as a child, skipping and vain, Formed by the eye and therefore, like the eye, Full of strange shapes, of habits and of forms, Varying in subjects as the eye doth roll To every varied object in his glance; Which parti-coated presence of loose love Put on by us, if, in your heavenly eyes, Have misbecomed our oaths and gravities, Those heavenly eyes that look into these faults Suggested us to make. Therefore, ladies, Our love being yours, the error that love makes Is likewise yours. We to ourselves prove false By being once false for ever to be true To those that make us both-fair ladies, you. And even that falsehood, in itself a sin, Thus purifies itself and turns to grace.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: We have received your letters, full of love; Your favours, the ambassadors of love; And in our maiden council rated them At courtship, pleasant jest, and courtesy, As bombast and as lining to the time. But more devout than this in our respects Have we not been; and therefore met your loves In their own fashion, like a merriment.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: Our letters, madam, showed much more than jest.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: So did our looks.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: We did not quote them so.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Now, at the latest minute of the hour, Grant us your loves.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: A time, methinks, too short To make a world-without-end bargain in. No, no, my lord, your Grace is perjured much, Full of dear guiltiness; and therefore this: If for my love-as there is no such cause- You will do aught, this shall you do for me: Your oath I will not trust, but go with speed To some forlorn and naked hermitage, Remote from all the pleasures of the world, There stay until the twelve celestial signs Have brought about the annual reckoning. If this austere insociable life Change not your offer made in heat of blood; If frosts and fasts, hard lodging and thin weeds, Nip not the gaudy blossoms of your love, But that it bear this trial, and last love; Then, at the expiration of the year, Come challenge me, challenge me by these deserts, And, by this virgin palm now kissing thine, I will be thine. And, till that instance, shut My woeful self up in a mournful house, Raining the tears of lamentation For the remembrance of my father's death. If this thou do deny, let our hands part, Neither entitled in the other's heart.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: If this, or more than this, I would deny, To flatter up these powers of mine with rest, The sudden hand of death close up mine eye! Hence hermit, then. My heart is in thy breast.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: And what to me, my love? But what to me? A wife?

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: A beard, fair health, and honesty; With threefold love I wish you all these three.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: O, shall I say, "I thank you, gentle wife"?

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: No so, my lord. A twelvemonth and a day I'll mark no words that smooth-faced wooers say. Come when the King doth to my lady come; Then, if I have much love, I'll give you some.

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: I'll serve thee true and faithfully till then.

dialogues.speaker: Katharine
dialogues.line: Yet swear not, lest ye be forsworn again.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: What says Maria?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: At the twelvemonth's end I'll change my black gown for a faithful friend.

dialogues.speaker: Longaville
dialogues.line: I'll stay with patience, but the time is long.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: The liker you; few taller are so young.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Studies my lady? Mistress, look on me. Behold the window of my heart, mine eye, What humble suit attends thy answer there. Impose some service on me for thy love.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Oft have I heard of you, my Lord Berowne, Before I saw you; and the world's large tongue Proclaims you for a man replete with mocks, Full of comparisons and wounding flouts, Which you on all estates will execute That lie within the mercy of your wit. To weed this wormwood from your fruitful brain, And therewithal to win me, if you please, Without the which I am not to be won, You shall this twelvemonth term from day to day Visit the speechless sick, and still converse With groaning wretches; and your task shall be, With all the fierce endeavour of your wit To enforce the pained impotent to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: To move wild laughter in the throat of death? It cannot be, it is impossible. Mirth cannot move a soul in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Rosaline
dialogues.line: Why, that's the way to choke a gibing spirit, Whose influence is begot of that loose grace Which shallow laughing hearers give to fools. A jest's prosperity lies in the ear Of him that hears it, never in the tongue Of him that makes it. Then, if sickly ears, Deafed with the clamours of their own dear groans, Will hear your idle scorns, continue then, And I will have you and that fault withal; But if they will not, throw away that spirit, And I shall find you empty of that fault, Right joyful of your reformation.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: A twelvemonth? Well, befall what will befall, I'll jest a twelvemonth in an hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Ay, sweet my lord, and so I take my leave.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: No, madam, we will bring you on your way.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: Our wooing doth not end like an old play. Jack hath not Jill. These ladies' courtesy Might well have made our sport a comedy.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Come, sir, it wants a twelvemonth and a day, And then 'twill end.

dialogues.speaker: Berowne
dialogues.line: That's too long for a play.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Sweet Majesty, vouchsafe me-

dialogues.speaker: Princess
dialogues.line: Was not that Hector?

dialogues.speaker: Dumaine
dialogues.line: The worthy knight of Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: I will kiss thy royal finger, and take leave. I am a votary; I have vowed to Jaquenetta to hold the plough for her sweet love three year. But, most esteemed Greatness, will you hear the dialogue that the two learned men have compiled in praise of the owl and the cuckoo? It should have followed in the end of our show.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Call them forth quickly; we will do so.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: Holla! Approach. This side is _Hiems_, Winter; this _Ver_, the Spring; the one maintained by the owl, th' other by the cuckoo. _Ver_, begin. The Song

dialogues.speaker: Spring
dialogues.line: When daisies pied and violets blue And lady-smocks all silver-white And cuckoo-buds of yellow hue Do paint the meadows with delight, The cuckoo then on every tree Mocks married men; for thus sings he: "Cuckoo! Cuckoo, cuckoo!" O, word of fear, Unpleasing to a married ear. When shepherds pipe on oaten straws, And merry larks are ploughmen's clocks, When turtles tread, and rooks and daws, And maidens bleach their summer smocks, The cuckoo then, on every tree, Mocks married men, for thus sings he: "Cuckoo! Cuckoo, cuckoo!" O, word of fear, Unpleasing to a married ear.

dialogues.speaker: Winter
dialogues.line: When icicles hang by the wall, And Dick the shepherd blows his nail, And Tom bears logs into the hall, And milk comes frozen home in pail, When blood is nipped, and ways be foul, Then nightly sings the staring owl: "Tu-whit, Tu-whoo!" A merry note, While greasy Joan doth keel the pot. When all aloud the wind doth blow, And coughing drowns the parson's saw, And birds sit brooding in the snow, And Marian's nose looks red and raw, When roasted crabs hiss in the bowl, Then nightly sings the staring owl: "Tu-whit, Tu-whoo!" A merry note, While greasy Joan doth keel the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Armado
dialogues.line: The words of Mercury are harsh after the songs of Apollo. You that way, we this way.
